noun.description: A settled or regular tendency or practice, especially one that is hard to give up.
examples: we stayed together out of habit
this can develop into a bad habit

noun.description: A long, loose garment worn by a member of a religious order or congregation.
A person's bodily condition or constitution.
examples: a victim to a consumptive habit
a boy habited as a serving lad

phrases: he checks his appearance out of force of habit
"I believe the biggest obstacles to an environmental tax shift are ignorance and force of habit," he says.
I did keep looking at my watch, though—force of habit.
All the play was gone from her actions and she just did them now from force of habit.
She will still be living in the area and says that she will still pop into the office from time to time for a coffee, and will, from force of habit, probably keep an eye on what's going on.
origin: Middle English: from Old French abit, habit, from Latin habitus condition, appearance, from habere have, consist of. The term originally meant dress, attire, later coming to denote physical or mental constitution.
